parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several habitat enhancement interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm showed mixed effects on invertebrate abundances.
[Statement 3]: One study found that creating hole habitats increased the abundance of brown crabs but not other mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 4]: Another study reported that creating hole habitats had mixed effects on invertebrate abundance depending on the species group.
[Statement 5]: Creating short flexible habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 6]: The effects of short flexible habitats on invertebrate abundance varied by survey week, species group, flexible habitat length, or site.
[Statement 7]: Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less produced mixed effects on non-mobile invertebrate abundance depending on the site.
[Statement 8]: Creating long flexible habitats larger than 50 mm resulted in mixed effects on mobile and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 9]: The effects of creating long flexible habitats on invertebrate abundance depended on the species group and survey week, or the flexible habitat's length and density.
[Statement 10]: One study found that creating long flexible habitats decreased mussel abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 11]: The long flexible habitats themselves supported higher biomass, which was mostly comprised of mussels.
[Statement 12]: Transplanting or seeding organisms showed positive results for invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 13]: One study found that transplanting sea urchins reduced non-native sea mat cover on kelps.
[Statement 14]: Another study reported that transplanting corals increased coral cover on structure surfaces.
[Statement 15]: Creating groove habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on the species group.
[Statement 16]: Creating pit habitats between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on invertebrate abundances depending on the species group.
[Statement 17]: Different artificial reef structures and materials showed varying results for invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 18]: Some studies found no differences in invertebrate abundances between different reef structures and materials.
[Statement 19]: Other studies found specific materials like oyster shell bags recruited more oysters and ribbed mussels compared to "ReefBall" breakwaters.
[Statement 20]: Ceasing or altering maintenance activities showed limited effects on overall invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 21]: One study found reducing the cleaning area on a structure increased seahorse abundance on its surfaces.
[Statement 22]: Creating combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges between 1 and 50 mm had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 23]: The effects of creating combinations of grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges on abundance depended on the structure's surface orientation.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which interventions can increase invertebrate abundance on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures provides several benefits for overall species richness.
[Statement 2]: Rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures supported higher combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species diversity and richness than structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 3]: Rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 4]: The combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness in created pools was similar to natural rock pools in some cases.
[Statement 5]: Creating pools, along with reducing the slope of a structure, increased the combined macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species richness on the structure.
[Statement 6]: Rock pools created on intertidal artificial structures were used by sea slugs, urchins, octopuses, macroalgae, invertebrates, and fishes.
[Statement 7]: When combined with other habitat features like holes, rock pools supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 8]: When combined with other habitat features like holes, rock pools increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness on structure surfaces.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the benefits of creating rock pools on intertidal artificial structures for overall species richness?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the general effects on biodiversity of creating linear depressions or elevations on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating linear depressions (grooves) and elevations (ridges/ledges) on intertidal artificial structures has varied effects on biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: Linear depressions, such as groove habitats of 1-50mm, show mixed effects on community composition.
[Statement 3]: Two of three studies found that linear depressions did not alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 4]: Grooves supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found that groove habitats increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found that groove habitats caused no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and/or diversity.
[Statement 7]: One study found that groove habitats had mixed effects on species richness and/or diversity depending on the site.
[Statement 8]: Some studies found that grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between them.
[Statement 9]: Linear elevations, such as small ridges or ledges of 1-50mm, generally showed less positive effects on biodiversity than linear depressions.
[Statement 10]: One study found no increase in combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness from small ridges.
[Statement 11]: Studies consistently found that small ridges supported lower species richness than grooves created between them.
[Statement 12]: Large ridges or ledges greater than 50mm showed more positive results for biodiversity than smaller ones.
[Statement 13]: One study reported that large ridges or ledges, when combined with grooves and small protrusions, increased combined macroalgae, microalgae, and invertebrate species diversity.
[Statement 14]: When grooves and small ridges/ledges are created together, some studies found this increased species diversity and/or richness.
[Statement 15]: When grooves and small ridges/ledges are created together, some studies found mixed effects on species diversity and/or richness depending on factors like depth, shore level, and site.
[Statement 16]: The effects of linear depressions and elevations on population abundance were mixed.
[Statement 17]: Some studies showed increased population abundances due to linear depressions and elevations, while others showed no effect or mixed results.
[Statement 18]: The effect of linear depressions and elevations on population abundance can depend on the specific organisms and environmental conditions.

[Statement 1]: Using shell-concrete or quarried rock in place of standard-concrete alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 2]: Using ECOncrete™ in place of standard-concrete or fibreglass alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 3]: Creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges in addition to using environmentally-sensitive materials alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 4]: ECOncrete™ surfaces with added habitats support mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that are absent from standard-concrete or fibreglass structure surfaces.
[Statement 5]: Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures alters the combined macroalgae and invertebrate or mobile invertebrate and fish community composition on and around the structures.
[Statement 6]: Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures also supports mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and/or fish species that are absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 7]: Long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures support macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that are absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
[Statement 8]: Groove habitats and small ledges created on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, alter the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 9]: Groove habitats and small ledges created on a subtidal artificial structure, along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, support non-mobile invertebrate species that are absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 10]: Creating textured surfaces is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
[Statement 11]: Creating groove habitats alone is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
[Statement 12]: Creating pit habitats is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
[Statement 13]: Creating short flexible habitats is a less consistently effective intervention for altering community composition.
[Statement 14]: Harvesting restrictions show effects on fish community composition but have limited evidence.
[Statement 15]: Ceasing or altering maintenance activities show minimal effects on community composition.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which interventions are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several habitat modifications on intertidal artificial structures in Australia have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance.
[Statement 2]: Creating short flexible habitats (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
[Statement 3]: One study found that creating short flexible habitats did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces during high tide.
[Statement 4]: Creating rock pools demonstrated mixed effects on fish abundance.
[Statement 5]: One Australian study on creating rock pools found mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species group and site.
[Statement 6]: Transplanting or seeding organisms onto structures showed neutral results for fish abundance.
[Statement 7]: Two Australian studies found that transplanting oysters and/or coralline algae did not increase fish abundance on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
[Statement 9]: Three Australian studies found that creating grooves and small protrusions/ridges/ledges did not increase combined fish or juvenile salmon abundances on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 10]: Creating small ridges or ledges (1-50 mm) showed neutral results for fish abundance.
[Statement 11]: One Australian study found that small ledges supported similar fish abundance to grooves created in between the ledges.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__For intertidal artificial structures in Australia, which habitat modifications have shown mixed or neutral results for fish abundance?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Harvesting restrictions on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from unrestricted structures.
[Statement 3]: Harvesting restrictions on subtidal artificial structures resulted in higher fish species richness compared with unrestricted structures.
[Statement 4]: Higher seabream abundances were found around structures with harvesting restrictions.
[Statement 5]: Long flexible habitats created on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
[Statement 6]: The creation of long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish abundance depending on the species, fish presence when the habitats were created, or the survey week.
[Statement 7]: Creating large swimthrough habitats in front of a subtidal artificial structure increased overall fish species richness and abundance on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: The effects of large swimthrough habitats varied depending on fish size class, species, and survey month.
[Statement 9]: The swimthrough habitats supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without swimthroughs.
[Statement 10]: Creating hole habitats on subtidal artificial structures supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 11]: Creating hole habitats had mixed effects on fish abundances depending on the species group.
[Statement 12]: In one case, creating hole habitats resulted in no increase in fish species abundances.
[Statement 13]: Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures altered fish community composition.
[Statement 14]: Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 15]: Pit habitats created on a subtidal artificial structure supported fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without the added habitat features.
[Statement 16]: The effects of pit habitats on fish abundances varied depending on the species group.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which interventions have been shown to benefit fish populations on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in Australian estuaries.
[Statement 2]: The conservation actions studied in Australian estuaries focused on habitat enhancement and organism transplantation approaches.
[Statement 3]: Creating long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures has been examined in three studies in southeast Australian estuaries.
[Statement 4]: Long flexible habitats on subtidal artificial structures supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate or fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
[Statement 5]: The long flexible habitats were found to be used by seahorses.
[Statement 6]: Long flexible habitats had mixed effects on fish species richness and abundance around structures, depending on fish presence when the habitats were created.
[Statement 7]: Creating hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures was studied in three Australian estuarine sites.
[Statement 8]: Hole habitats supported macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate species absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 9]: Hole habitats on intertidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity and richness.
[Statement 10]: Hole habitats were observed being used by sea slugs, urchins and octopuses.
[Statement 11]: Hole habitats had mixed effects on limpet abundance depending on shore level and site.
[Statement 12]: Creating groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures has been extensively studied with seven studies conducted in southeast Australian estuaries.
[Statement 13]: Grooves on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrate species that were absent from structure surfaces without grooves.
[Statement 14]: Grooves supported higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between the grooves.
[Statement 15]: Grooves did not consistently increase combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition or abundance on structure surfaces.
[Statement 16]: Transplanting or seeding organisms onto intertidal artificial structures was examined in seven Australian estuarine studies.
[Statement 17]: Transplanted oysters on intertidal artificial structures supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without transplanted oysters.
[Statement 18]: Transplanting oysters had mixed effects on combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity, depending on site and presence of grooves and small ridges on surfaces.
[Statement 19]: Transplanting oysters increased mobile invertebrate species richness.
[Statement 20]: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site.
[Statement 21]: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition.
[Statement 22]: Creating short flexible habitats on intertidal artificial structures decreased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness during low tide.
[Statement 23]: Using environmentally-sensitive materials on both intertidal and subtidal artificial structures has been studied in Australian estuaries.
[Statement 24]: Using sandstone in place of basalt on artificial structures had mixed effects on community composition depending on site.
[Statement 25]: Reduced-pH-concrete surfaces on artificial structures supported species absent from standard-concrete surfaces.
[Statement 26]: Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures was examined in Australian estuarine studies.
[Statement 27]: Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures increased combined macroalgae, invertebrate and fish species richness.
[Statement 28]: Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures did not increase macroalgal, oyster or mobile invertebrate abundance.
[Statement 29]: Transplanting organisms onto subtidal artificial structures was studied in one Australian estuarine site.
[Statement 30]: Transplanting sea urchins onto subtidal artificial structures reduced the cover of non-native sea mat on kelps growing on the structure.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What conservation actions for artificial structures have been studied in estuaries in Australia, and what were the outcomes?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Creating linear habitat features such as grooves, ridges or ledges on intertidal artificial structures produces varied effects on biodiversity.
[Statement 2]: Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges can alter the combined community composition of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 3]: The effects of groove habitats and small ridges or ledges on community composition depend on site-specific factors, the presence of water-retaining and light-shading covers, and the size and arrangement of the features.
[Statement 4]: Linear features like grooves, ridges, and ledges support species that are absent from artificial structure surfaces that lack these features.
[Statement 5]: Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges on structure surfaces has been found to increase the combined species diversity and/or richness of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 6]: The effects of grooves and ridges on species richness and diversity vary depending on the depth or height of the features, the shore level, the species group, and the site.
[Statement 7]: Grooves on artificial structures support higher species richness than small ridges or ledges created between the grooves.
[Statement 8]: Species diversity in grooves versus ridges varies depending on the depth of the groove.
[Statement 9]: The responses of population abundance to the creation of linear habitat features were mixed across studies.
[Statement 10]: Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges did not always increase the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 11]: The abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates increased when linear features were partially-covered with water-retaining and light-shading covers.
[Statement 12]: The abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates increased when linear features were combined with large ledges.
[Statement 13]: The creation of linear habitat features had mixed effects on the abundances of mobile invertebrates, non-mobile invertebrates, limpets, mussels, juvenile oysters, and barnacles.
[Statement 14]: The effects of linear habitat features on invertebrate abundances depended on the feature's depth or height, the presence of large ledges or covers, the shore level, and the site.
[Statement 15]: Creating groove habitats and small ridges or ledges generally does not increase fish species richness or abundance.
[Statement 16]: Behavioral effects of creating linear features on intertidal artificial structures included increased feeding activity for juvenile salmon.
[Statement 17]: Behavioral effects of creating linear features on intertidal artificial structures included an increased amount of time that benthic fishes spent interacting with structure surfaces.
[Statement 18]: Large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm in size led to an increased abundance of mussels and limpets, but not barnacles.
[Statement 19]: Large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm in size led to increased rockweed abundance.
[Statement 20]: Groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures were found to be colonized by microalgal species.
[Statement 21]: Groove habitats on intertidal artificial structures were used by mussels and periwinkles.
[Statement 22]: The effectiveness of linear habitat features appears to depend heavily on design parameters including the size, arrangement, and depth of the features.
[Statement 23]: The effectiveness of linear habitat features appears to depend heavily on the presence of additional features or covers.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the general effects of creating linear habitat features, such as grooves, ridges or ledges, on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most consistently effective habitat creation methods for increasing species richness on subtidal artificial structures are combinations of multiple small-scale features.
[Statement 2]: The use of ECOncrete materials is one of the most consistently effective habitat creation methods for increasing species richness on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 3]: Creating hole habitats larger than 50 mm, along with grooves, environmentally-sensitive material, and pits or small ledges, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on and around structures.
[Statement 4]: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges (1-50 mm), along with holes and environmentally-sensitive material, increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species richness and diversity on structure surfaces.
[Statement 5]: Groove habitats (1-50 mm) created along with holes, pits, and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity.
[Statement 6]: Pit habitats (1-50 mm) created with holes, grooves, and environmentally-sensitive material increased combined macroalgae and invertebrate species diversity on structure surfaces.
[Statement 7]: Large adjoining cavities or swim-through habitats larger than 100 mm increased overall fish species richness on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 8]: Using ECOncrete material along with creating texture, grooves, holes, pits and/or small ledges increased species diversity and/or richness on and around structures.
[Statement 9]: Transplanting oysters onto subtidal artificial structures increased combined invertebrate and fish species richness and diversity on and around structure surfaces.
[Statement 10]: Evidence indicates that combinations of multiple habitat features appear more consistently effective at enhancing species richness than single features.
[Statement 11]: The use of specialized materials like ECOncrete appears most consistently effective at enhancing species richness.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which habitat creation methods appear most consistently effective at increasing overall species richness on subtidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures through structural modifications is mixed and limited.
[Statement 2]: Grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges measuring 1-50 mm can alter community composition.
[Statement 3]: Grooves and small protrusions, ridges, or ledges measuring 1-50 mm can support non-mobile invertebrate species absent from unmodified surfaces.
[Statement 4]: Groove habitats and small ledges have been found to increase the combined species richness and diversity of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 5]: The effects of groove habitats and small ledges can be mixed depending on surface orientation.
[Statement 6]: Groove habitats measuring 1-50 mm can alter community composition and increase species diversity when combined with other features like holes and pits.
[Statement 7]: Groove habitats supported macroalgae, non-mobile invertebrate and fish species that were absent from structures without habitat features.
[Statement 8]: Hole habitats larger than 50 mm altered community composition and supported species absent from unmodified structures.
[Statement 9]: Holes on subtidal artificial structures increased species richness and/or diversity when combined with other structural features.
[Statement 10]: Holes on subtidal artificial structures increased brown crab abundance.
[Statement 11]: Holes on subtidal artificial structures had mixed effects on other species groups.
[Statement 12]: Pit habitats measuring 1-50 mm altered community composition and increased species diversity when combined with holes, grooves and environmentally-sensitive material.
[Statement 13]: The effects of pit habitats on the abundances of different species groups were mixed.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of creating large ridges or ledges greater than 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of creating crevice habitats greater than 50 mm on subtidal artificial structures.
[Statement 16]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing the slope of subtidal artificial structures.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for enhancing biodiversity on subtidal artificial structures by creating crevices, protrusions, ridges, ledges, or by reducing their slope?
_claude-sonnet-4__Which habitat creation methods are most consistently effective at altering the overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Rock pools are the most consistently effective habitat creation method for altering overall community composition on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Rock pools supported macroalgae, mobile invertebrate, non-mobile invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without pools.
[Statement 3]: Rock pools created a different combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition compared to surfaces without pools.
[Statement 4]: Pit habitats demonstrate consistent effectiveness in altering the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 5]: Pit habitats supported macroalgae, invertebrate, and fish species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitats.
[Statement 6]: Hole habitats altered the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 7]: Hole habitats supported species that were absent from structure surfaces without added habitat features.
[Statement 8]: Long flexible habitats altered the combined macroalgae and non-mobile invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 9]: Long flexible habitats supported macroalgae, mobile and non-mobile invertebrates that were absent from structure surfaces without flexible habitats.
[Statement 10]: Groove habitats showed mixed results for altering the combined macroalgae and invertebrate community composition on structure surfaces.
[Statement 11]: Small ridges or ledges showed inconsistent effects on altering community composition.

[Statement 1]: Several limitations and mixed results have been identified regarding adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures.
[Statement 2]: Creating natural rocky reef topography did not increase the combined species richness of macroalgae and invertebrates on structure surfaces.
[Statement 3]: Creating natural rocky reef topography had mixed effects on barnacle and mobile invertebrate abundances, with outcomes depending on the site.
[Statement 4]: Creating pit habitats has shown variable effectiveness in enhancing biodiversity.
[Statement 5]: Studies have found that pit creation did not alter community composition in some cases.
[Statement 6]: Some studies found that pit creation did not increase species richness.
[Statement 7]: One study found that creating pit habitats decreased the combined abundance of macroalgae and invertebrates.
[Statement 8]: The effects of pit habitats were frequently site-dependent.
[Statement 9]: The effects of pit habitats varied based on the size and arrangement of the pits.
[Statement 10]: Creating textured surfaces had mixed effects on species richness, depending on the type of texture and the site.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found no increase in macroalgal or invertebrate abundance on structure surfaces with created textures.
[Statement 12]: Reducing the slope of intertidal artificial structures showed limited benefits for biodiversity.
[Statement 13]: One study found that reducing the slope of a structure did not increase macroalgal abundance or the abundance of oysters and mobile invertebrates.
[Statement 14]: Creating hole habitats showed some limitations for enhancing biodiversity.
[Statement 15]: Studies reported no increase in macroalgal abundance from the creation of hole habitats.
[Statement 16]: Creating hole habitats had mixed effects on limpet abundance, depending on the shore level and site.
[Statement 17]: The effectiveness of topographical complexity modifications appears to be highly context-dependent.
[Statement 18]: Results of adding topographical complexity vary significantly based on site conditions, specific design parameters, and target species.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the potential negative impacts or limitations of adding topographical complexity to enhance biodiversity on intertidal artificial structures?
_claude-sonnet-4__Besides choosing different construction materials, what other interventions can modify the surface of artificial structures to benefit biodiversity?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several surface modification interventions can be applied to artificial structures to benefit biodiversity beyond material choice.
[Statement 2]: Creating textured surfaces of 1 mm or less on artificial structures can alter the community composition on the surfaces of those structures.
[Statement 3]: Studies have shown that textured surfaces can cause changes in macroalgae and invertebrate communities and support species absent from non-textured surfaces.
[Statement 4]: Adding small protrusions of 1-50 mm to artificial structures has shown mixed effects on macroalgal abundance, with results depending on the species.
[Statement 5]: Creating grooves and small protrusions, ridges or ledges of 1-50 mm together on artificial structures can alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity.
[Statement 6]: The addition of grooves, protrusions, ridges, or ledges to artificial structures can support species absent from structures without these features.
[Statement 7]: Short flexible habitats of 1-50 mm can be installed on structures to alter community composition.
[Statement 8]: Reducing the slope of artificial structures can increase species richness when combined with other modifications like creating rock pools.
[Statement 9]: Creating groove habitats of 1-50 mm on structures can alter community composition and increase species diversity.
[Statement 10]: Groove habitats on structures can support species groups that are not found on unmodified structures.
[Statement 11]: Creating pit habitats of 1-50 mm on artificial structures can alter community composition and increase species diversity.
[Statement 12]: Natural rocky reef topography can be created on structures, though the effects on biodiversity vary.
[Statement 13]: Organisms can be transplanted or seeded onto artificial structures to alter community composition and increase species richness and diversity.
[Statement 14]: Green infrastructure, including green roofs, can be established in urban areas.
[Statement 15]: Green infrastructure may have lower species richness compared to urban parks.
[Statement 16]: Applying textured coatings to specific structures like turbines may have limited effects on wildlife activity.
